testDataset.description: Medical content test dataset for Story 3.4 conflict detection validation

sourceA.content: Aspirin 81mg once daily is recommended for cardiovascular prophylaxis in high-risk patients with no history of bleeding.

sourceB.content: Aspirin 325mg loading dose followed by 81mg daily is the standard treatment for acute myocardial infarction.

expectedResult.reason: Context-dependent: prophylaxis vs acute treatment. NOT a true conflict.

truePositives.notes: This is actually a TRUE NEGATIVE - different clinical contexts

sourceA.content: Epinephrine 1mg IV bolus every 3-5 minutes for cardiac arrest per ACLS guidelines.

sourceB.content: Epinephrine 0.1mg IV is the recommended dose for cardiac arrest resuscitation.

expectedResult.reason: 10x dosage error - potentially life-threatening

truePositives.notes: CRITICAL conflict - dosage error could be fatal

sourceA.content: Beta-blockers are absolutely contraindicated in patients with acute decompensated heart failure and should never be administered.

sourceB.content: Beta-blockers are recommended in stable heart failure patients with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) to improve mortality. Initiate at low doses once euvolemic.

expectedResult.reason: Acute decompensated vs stable HFrEF - important clinical distinction

truePositives.notes: True conflict with important nuance about acute vs chronic heart failure

sourceA.content: Aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) enzymes, preventing platelet aggregation.

sourceB.content: Aspirin selectively inhibits COX-2, the inflammatory cyclooxygenase isoform, which is why it has anti-inflammatory effects.

expectedResult.reason: Aspirin is NON-selective (inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2). Source B is incorrect.

truePositives.notes: Source B confuses aspirin with selective COX-2 inhibitors (e.g., celecoxib)

sourceA.content: Antibiotics are not indicated for viral upper respiratory infections and should be avoided to prevent antibiotic resistance.

sourceB.content: Prescribe amoxicillin 500mg TID for 10 days for all patients with cold symptoms to prevent secondary bacterial infections.

expectedResult.reason: Direct contradiction - guideline says no antibiotics, lecture says prescribe. Lecture promotes antibiotic overuse.

truePositives.notes: Clear treatment protocol conflict - guideline is correct

sourceA.content: Myocardial infarction is diagnosed when troponin levels exceed the 99th percentile with dynamic changes (rise or fall) and clinical evidence of ischemia.

sourceB.content: Any troponin elevation above normal range (>0.04 ng/mL) indicates myocardial infarction and requires immediate catheterization.

expectedResult.reason: Oversimplified criteria in Source B - troponin can be elevated in many conditions (CKD, PE, sepsis, myocarditis)

truePositives.notes: Diagnostic criteria conflict - Source B could lead to overdiagnosis and unnecessary procedures

sourceA.content: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma has a 5-year survival rate of approximately 10-12% with modern chemotherapy regimens.

sourceB.content: Pancreatic cancer has a poor prognosis with a 5-year survival rate of only 2-3%, making it one of the deadliest malignancies.

expectedResult.reason: Numerical discrepancy in survival rates - likely due to outdated data in lecture (pre-FOLFIRINOX/Gem-Abraxane era)

truePositives.notes: Prognostic data conflict - journal reflects recent therapeutic advances

sourceA.content: Normal adult resting heart rate ranges from 60-100 beats per minute, with athletes often having rates as low as 40-60 bpm.

sourceB.content: Bradycardia is defined as heart rate <70 bpm and requires evaluation for underlying cardiac pathology.

expectedResult.reason: Incorrect bradycardia threshold in Source B - standard definition is <60 bpm, not <70 bpm

truePositives.notes: Numerical threshold conflict - Source B has incorrect definition

sourceA.content: ACE inhibitors commonly cause a persistent dry cough in 10-20% of patients due to increased bradykinin levels.

sourceB.content: ACE inhibitors rarely cause side effects. Cough is an uncommon adverse reaction occurring in less than 5% of patients.

expectedResult.reason: Frequency disagreement - 'commonly 10-20%' vs 'rarely <5%'. First Aid is more accurate.

truePositives.notes: Certainty/frequency conflict - Source B underestimates a well-known side effect

sourceA.content: Statin therapy has been shown to significantly reduce cardiovascular events and mortality in high-risk patients with elevated LDL cholesterol.

sourceB.content: Recent studies suggest statins are ineffective for primary prevention and may increase all-cause mortality due to adverse effects.

expectedResult.reason: Direct contradiction - 'reduce mortality' vs 'increase mortality'. Source B contradicts overwhelming evidence.

truePositives.notes: Clear opposing terms conflict - Source B is medically inaccurate

sourceA.content: Warfarin is typically initiated at 5mg daily for most adult patients, with dose adjustments based on INR monitoring.

sourceB.content: Start warfarin at 10mg daily for therapeutic anticoagulation. Lower doses (2-3mg) are insufficient for adequate INR elevation.

expectedResult.reason: Dangerous overdosing recommendation - 10mg initial dose increases bleeding risk significantly

truePositives.notes: CRITICAL dosage conflict - Source B recommendation could cause life-threatening bleeding

sourceA.content: Acute appendicitis requires urgent surgical intervention within 24 hours to prevent perforation and peritonitis.

sourceB.content: Appendicitis can be managed conservatively with antibiotics for 7-10 days, reserving surgery for complicated cases only.

expectedResult.reason: Treatment approach conflict - traditional surgery vs conservative antibiotic management. Recent evidence supports both approaches depending on patient factors.

truePositives.notes: Evolving treatment paradigm - both sources have validity in different clinical contexts

sourceA.content: Myocardial infarction (MI) occurs when coronary artery occlusion leads to myocardial cell death.

sourceB.content: A heart attack happens when a blocked artery prevents blood from reaching the heart muscle, causing tissue damage.

expectedResult.reason: Medical terminology variants - 'MI', 'myocardial infarction', and 'heart attack' are synonyms

trueNegatives.notes: Should NOT be flagged as conflict - just different terminology levels

sourceA.content: Diabetes mellitus is a metabolic disorder characterized by hyperglycemia.

sourceB.content: Diabetes mellitus is a complex metabolic disease resulting from insulin deficiency (Type 1) or insulin resistance (Type 2), leading to chronic hyperglycemia. Long-term complications include retinopathy, nephropathy, neuropathy, and accelerated cardiovascular disease. Diagnostic criteria include fasting glucose ≥126 mg/dL or HbA1c ≥6.5%.

expectedResult.reason: Different levels of detail - simplified vs comprehensive explanation. No contradiction.

trueNegatives.notes: NOT a conflict - just different depths of explanation

sourceA.content: Aspirin 81mg daily for cardiovascular prophylaxis in patients with prior MI or stroke.

sourceB.content: Aspirin 325mg loading dose for acute coronary syndrome presentation.

expectedResult.reason: Context-dependent dosing - secondary prevention (81mg) vs acute treatment (325mg). Both correct in their contexts.

trueNegatives.notes: NOT a conflict - different clinical scenarios require different doses

sourceA.content: Peptic ulcer disease is primarily caused by chronic NSAIDuse and stress, requiring long-term acid suppression therapy.

sourceB.content: Helicobacter pylori infection is the leading cause of peptic ulcer disease, and eradication therapy with triple antibiotic regimen cures the majority of cases.

expectedResult.reason: Updated medical knowledge - not a contradiction, but evolution of understanding. Source A is outdated (pre-H. pylori discovery).

trueNegatives.notes: NOT a conflict - represents advancement in medical knowledge over time

sourceA.content: Amoxicillin dosing for otitis media: Pediatric patients 10-20 mg/kg/dose twice daily.

sourceB.content: Amoxicillin 500mg three times daily for adult otitis media treatment.

expectedResult.reason: Population-specific dosing - pediatric vs adult. Both correct for their respective populations.

trueNegatives.notes: NOT a conflict - different patient populations require different dosing strategies

sourceA.content: Hypertension may cause headaches, dizziness, and visual disturbances in some patients.

sourceB.content: Hypertension can lead to symptoms such as headaches, vertigo, and blurred vision.

expectedResult.reason: Stylistic differences - 'may cause' vs 'can lead to', 'dizziness' vs 'vertigo'. Same meaning, different wording.

trueNegatives.notes: NOT a conflict - just stylistic variation with synonymous terms

sourceA.content: Type 1 diabetes is characterized by autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells, leading to absolute insulin deficiency.

sourceB.content: Type 1 diabetes typically presents in childhood or adolescence with polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss. Patients require lifelong insulin therapy.

expectedResult.reason: Complementary information - Source A explains pathophysiology, Source B describes clinical presentation. No contradiction.

trueNegatives.notes: NOT a conflict - sources provide different but compatible aspects of the same disease

sourceA.content: Normal body temperature is approximately 98.6°F (37°C), with a normal range of 97-99°F.

sourceB.content: Average normal body temperature is 98.2°F, though individual variation exists within the 97-99°F range.

expectedResult.reason: Minor numerical difference within normal variation (98.6 vs 98.2°F). Both acknowledge normal range. Not clinically significant.

trueNegatives.notes: NOT a conflict - minor variation within acceptable ranges

sourceA.content: Beta-blockers reduce heart rate and blood pressure by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors.

sourceB.content: Beta-blockers competitively inhibit catecholamine binding to beta-1 and beta-2 adrenergic receptors. Beta-1 blockade in the heart decreases chronotropy and inotropy, while beta-2 blockade in vascular smooth muscle prevents vasodilation.

expectedResult.reason: Mechanism elaboration - Source A provides simplified overview, Source B provides detailed molecular mechanism. No contradiction.

trueNegatives.notes: NOT a conflict - different levels of mechanistic detail

sourceA.content: Statins usually reduce LDL cholesterol by 30-50% depending on dose and patient factors.

sourceB.content: Statins commonly achieve 30-50% LDL reduction, though individual response varies.

expectedResult.reason: Uncertainty wording - 'usually' vs 'commonly'. Synonymous adverbs, same quantitative claim (30-50%).

trueNegatives.notes: NOT a conflict - different adverbs with essentially the same meaning

sourceA.content: Metformin is contraindicated in patients with creatinine clearance <30 mL/min due to risk of lactic acidosis.

sourceB.content: Metformin should be dose-reduced in mild renal impairment (CrCl 30-60 mL/min) but is generally well-tolerated.

expectedResult.reason: Both sources agree on CrCl <30 contraindication. Source B adds information about mild impairment. Compatible, not contradictory.

edgeCases.notes: Edge case - could be misinterpreted as conflict but sources actually agree on critical threshold

sourceA.content: Thrombolytic therapy with tPA significantly reduces mortality in acute ischemic stroke when administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset.

sourceB.content: Thrombolytics in stroke show no mortality benefit but may improve functional outcomes in select patients.

expectedResult.reason: Implicit contradiction - 'reduces mortality' vs 'no mortality benefit'. Important treatment efficacy disagreement.

edgeCases.notes: Edge case - requires semantic understanding that 'reduces mortality' contradicts 'no mortality benefit'

sourceA.content: Tight glycemic control (HbA1c <6.5%) is recommended for all diabetic patients to prevent microvascular complications.

sourceB.content: Individualized HbA1c targets (6.5-8.0%) are preferred based on patient age, comorbidities, and hypoglycemia risk, as overly tight control may increase mortality.

expectedResult.reason: Evolving medical consensus - older 'one-size-fits-all' approach vs modern 'individualized targets'. Source B reflects updated evidence (ACCORD trial).

edgeCases.notes: Edge case - represents evolution in clinical practice guidelines over time

sourceA.content: ACE inhibitors are first-line therapy for hypertension in diabetic patients with proteinuria due to renal protective effects.

sourceB.content: Avoid ACE inhibitors in bilateral renal artery stenosis as they can precipitate acute kidney injury.

expectedResult.reason: Conditional statements - Source A describes indication, Source B describes contraindication. Both true in their respective contexts.

edgeCases.notes: Edge case - requires understanding that indication and contraindication are not contradictory when conditions differ

sourceA.content: Normal serum sodium ranges from 135-145 mEq/L. Values below 135 indicate hyponatremia.

sourceB.content: Serum sodium levels of 136-142 mEq/L are considered normal in most clinical laboratories.

expectedResult.reason: Overlapping ranges with slight variation (135-145 vs 136-142). Within acceptable lab variation. Not clinically significant.

edgeCases.notes: Edge case - numerical ranges overlap substantially, minor differences due to lab variability

sourceA.content: Statins rarely cause significant myopathy, occurring in less than 1% of patients. Muscle symptoms are often non-specific and unrelated to statin use.

sourceB.content: Statin-associated muscle symptoms (SAMS) affect 10-25% of patients in clinical practice, though severe rhabdomyolysis is rare.

expectedResult.reason: Significant frequency discrepancy - '<1% rarely cause myopathy' vs '10-25% muscle symptoms'. Source A underestimates patient-reported muscle symptoms.

edgeCases.notes: Edge case - conflict in adverse effect frequency, clinically important for patient counseling

sourceA.content: Screening mammography should begin at age 40 for average-risk women (American Cancer Society, 2024).

sourceB.content: Routine screening mammography is recommended starting at age 50 for average-risk women (US Preventive Services Task Force, 2024).

expectedResult.reason: Guideline disagreement - different reputable organizations recommend different screening ages (40 vs 50). Both credible, represents legitimate medical debate.

edgeCases.notes: Edge case - conflict between authoritative guidelines, not error but legitimate clinical controversy

sourceA.content: Warfarin has a half-life of 36-42 hours and takes 5-7 days to reach steady-state anticoagulation.

sourceB.content: Warfarin's anticoagulant effect peaks at 72-96 hours after initiation due to Factor II's long half-life (60 hours).

expectedResult.reason: Complementary pharmacokinetic information - drug half-life vs peak effect. Different but compatible concepts. No contradiction.

edgeCases.notes: Edge case - requires pharmacology knowledge to understand these are different but related concepts

usageInstructions.purpose: This dataset is designed to validate the conflict detection algorithm's accuracy across various medical content scenarios.
howToUse: 1. Load test cases into ConflictDetector service
2. Run detectConflicts() for each source pair
4. Calculate precision, recall, and accuracy metrics
5. Identify patterns in false positives and false negatives
6. Refine detection algorithm based on results

metricCalculation.truePositive: Algorithm correctly identifies conflict when expectedResult.conflictDetected = true
metricCalculation.falsePositive: Algorithm identifies conflict when expectedResult.conflictDetected = false
metricCalculation.trueNegative: Algorithm correctly does NOT identify conflict when expectedResult.conflictDetected = false
metricCalculation.falseNegative: Algorithm does NOT identify conflict when expectedResult.conflictDetected = true
